title: Provides homemaker services may be provided by private home aides
summary: Provides homemaker services may be provided by private home aides, subject to certain requirements, not only certified home care agencies; includes homemaker services engaged through private home aides within the definition of "home health aide services"; and provides homemaker services shall be reimbursable through the New York state partnership for long term care.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2098

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public health law, the insurance law and the social
services law, in relation to the provision of homemaker
services

PURPOSE:
This bill provides that homemaker services
may be provided by
private home aides.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

Section 1 amends subdivision 4 of section 3602 of the public health law.
It permits homemaker services to be provided by a private home health
aide as long as the aide has met the standards of the department of
family assistance. The services must also be reimbursable through the
NYS Partnership for Long Term Care.

Section 2 amends subparagraph (A) of paragraph 6 of subsection (i) of
section 3216 of the insurance law. Home care services may be provided
by a private aide as long as the aide is certified and prescribed by
a physician. This section establishes the parameters of "homemaker
services." A private home aide shall meet the standards provided by
the department of family assistance. These services shall he
reimbursable through the NYS Partnership for Long Term Care.

Section 3 amends subparagraph (D) of paragraph 1 of subsection (k) of
section 3221 of the insurance law. These provisions are the same as
section 2.

Section 4 amends subparagraphs (B) and (C) of paragraph 3 of
subsection (a) of section 4303 of the insurance law to make the
provisions consistent with bill sections 2 & 3.

Section 5 amends paragraph (b) of subdivision 1 of section 367- f of
the social services law to make provisions consistent with the
amendments to the insurance law, as outline in bill sections 2, 3, & 4.

Section 6 directs the department of insurance to compare expenditures
and utilization patterns for claims for home care services covered by
individual and group accident and health insurance.

Section 7 enacts this legislation on the 120th day after it shall
become law.

EXISTING LAW:

Section 460.1 defines "homemaker services" as a specialized service
which complements casework service of an agency. It is provided upon
the recommendation of a physician to provide services in a person's
home for the purposes of maintaining normal household operations or
during periods of special circumstances. These services include
household tasks such as marketing/shopping, preparation and serving
of meals, cleaning, light laundry, ironing, and mending. Personal
services include assistance with bathing, care of small children or
elderly or disabled adults, payment of bills, errands, and
accompaniment to a doctor's appointment or clinic.

JUSTIFICATION:
This bill allows individuals to hire a private aide to perform
homemaker services and still be reimbursed through the NYS
Partnership for Long Term Care. Current law stipulates that homemaker
services must be provided through a certified employment agency.
Under the provisions of this legislation, the aide must still conform
to the certifications outlined by the appropriate departments and the
services must still be prescribed by a physician. Private certified
aides can already be hired by persons in need, but the services are
not reimbursable through the Partnership for Long Term Care. These
provisions remedy this situation, allowing aides to be hired
privately and, perhaps, at a lesser rate than that charged by
employment agencies.

With much of our state's elderly population relegated to fixed
incomes, every penny saved is important.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
New bill.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the 120th day after it shall become law.
